message.content:
cs.RO, cs.CV, cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.SY. 

The paper presents a novel regrasp control policy that uses tactile sensing to plan local grasp adjustments. This involves constructing a tactile-based grasp quality metric using a deep convolutional neural network trained on over 2800 grasps, simulating tactile imprints associated with robot motions relative to the initial grasp by performing rigid-body transformations of the given tactile measurements, and choosing the regrasp action to maximize the grasp quality. The paper's focus on robotics and machine learning suggests that it is most likely to belong to the cs.RO (Robotics) sub-category. However, the use of deep convolutional neural networks and cross-validation suggests that it could also belong to the cs.CV (Computer Vision) and cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) sub-categories. The paper's experimental evaluation and focus on grasp quality suggest that it could also belong to the cs.LG (Machine Learning) sub-category. Finally, the use of tactile sensing and regrasp control policy suggest that it could also belong to the cs.SY (Systems and Control) sub-category.
